com.googlecode.streamflyer.xml
Class XmlVersionModifier

java.lang.Object
  com.googlecode.streamflyer.xml.XmlVersionModifier
All Implemented Interfaces:
Modifier
public class XmlVersionModifier
extends Object
implements Modifier

Replaces the XML version in the XML prolog with the given XML version. Adds an XML prolog if the stream does not contain an XML prolog.

Contents

1. How and when do I use this modifier?
2. Do I have to care about BOMs at the beginning of the stream?
3. Is there any known limitation?
4. How much memory does the modifier consume?

1. How and when do I use this modifier?

This modifier is an alternative to InvalidXmlCharacterModifier if you a have characters in an XML stream that are valid for XML 1.1 documents but invalid for XML 1.1 documents. In this case you use this modifier to change the XML version in the prolog of the document.

EXAMPLE: 

// choose the input stream to modify
ByteArrayInputStream inputStream = new ByteArrayInputStream(
        bytesWithBom);

// wrap the input stream by BOM skipping reader
Reader reader = new XmlStreamReader(inputStream);

// create the reader that changes the XML version to 1.1
ModifyingReader modifyingReader = new ModifyingReader(reader,
        new XmlVersionModifier("1.1", 8192));

// use the modifying reader instead of the original reader
String xml = IOUtils.toString(modifyingReader);

assertTrue(xml.startsWith("<?xml version='1.1'"));

2. Do I have to care about BOMs at the beginning of the stream?

Yes, you must use a BOM skipping reader that wraps the input stream. Apache's Commons IO XmlStreamReader does this for you.

3. Is there any known limitation?

Yes, this modifier throws a XmlPrologRidiculouslyLongException if the prolog of the XML document contains more than INITIAL_NUMBER_OF_CHARACTERS characters. This can only happen if there is a lot of whitespace within the prolog, which is highly unlikely but not forbidden by the XML specification. You should know that even the XmlReader of Apache Commons which you probably use to detect the encoding cannot deal with such a kind of prolog.

4. How much memory does the modifier consume?

The memory consumption of this modifier during the stream processing is roughly given by the second argument of XmlVersionModifier(String, int) but the initial memory consumption is given by INITIAL_NUMBER_OF_CHARACTERS.

27.06.2011

rwoo

Method Detail

modify

public AfterModification modify(StringBuilder characterBuffer,
                                int firstModifiableCharacterInBuffer,
                                boolean endOfStreamHit)
Description copied from interface: Modifier
Processes the characters in the given character buffer, i.e. deletes or replaces or inserts characters, or keeps the characters as they are.

Specified by:
modify in interface Modifier
Parameters:
characterBuffer - The next characters provided from the modifiable stream. It contains the modifiable characters, (optionally) preceded by unmodifiable characters.

The modifier can modify the content of the buffer as appropriate the modifier must not modify the unmodifiable characters, i.e. the characters before position firstModifiableCharacterInBufferIndex must not be modified.

Your modifier should manage the capacity of the buffer on its own - as the optimal management of the capacity depends on the specific purpose of the modifier.

The given buffer must be never null.

firstModifiableCharacterInBuffer - index of the first modifiable character in the buffer. The index of the first character in the buffer is zero. If there is not modifiable character in the buffer, then this value is equal the length of the buffer.
endOfStreamHit - True if no more characters can be read from the stream, i.e. the character buffer contains the all the characters up to the end of the stream.
Returns:
Returns an object that defines how ModifyingReader or ModifyingWriter shall behave before calling Modifier.modify(StringBuilder, int, boolean) again.
See Also:
Modifier.modify(java.lang.StringBuilder, int, boolean)
